thread.title: BARC euthanization rate drops below 10 percent
thread.title_full: BARC euthanization rate drops below 10 percent

author: Rebecca Elliott, Houston Chronicle
title: BARC euthanization rate drops below 10 percent

organizations.name: ap/ black bear conservation committee image

text:
By Rebecca Elliott , Houston Chronicle Updated 3:50 pm, Wednesday, February 8, 2017 Photo: Karen Warren, Houston Chronicle Image 1 of / 14 Close Image 1 of 14 Brenna Pickard, holds a tuxedo kitten while looking around the kitten room at BARC on Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Houston. Mayor Sylvester Turner said on Feb. 8, 2017 that BARC put down less than 9 percent of the animals it took over at the end of 2016. Click through the slideshow to see endangered species that live in Texas. Brenna Pickard, holds a tuxedo kitten while looking around the kitten room at BARC on Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Houston. Mayor Sylvester Turner said on Feb. 8, 2017 that BARC put down less than 9 Photo: Karen Warren, Houston Chronicle Image 2 of 14 
Endangered or threatened Texas animals 
Endangered or threatened Texas animals Photo: Texas Wildlife Image 3 of 14 Black-footed ferret The black-footed ferret depends on prairie dogs for food, and therefore it lives near prairie dog habitat. Numbers of prairie dogs have shrunk in Texas, and the ferret has not been seen here since 1963. It's possible it may live near bigger priarie dog town in the Panhandle. less Black-footed ferret The black-footed ferret depends on prairie dogs for food, and therefore it lives near prairie dog habitat. Numbers of prairie dogs have shrunk in Texas, and the ferret has not been seen here ... more Image 4 of 14 Jaguarundi This cool cat, just a little bigger than a typical house cat, is now rarely seen in Texas and then only in the Rio Grande Valley. It prefers very thick brush near a water source, and most of its habitat has been cleared for human use. less Jaguarundi This cool cat, just a little bigger than a typical house cat, is now rarely seen in Texas and then only in the Rio Grande Valley. It prefers very thick brush near a water source, and most of its ... more Photo: Associated Press Image 5 of 14 
Ocelot 
This endangered cat is about the size of a bobcat and is remarkable for its stunning markings. It used to roam a good bit of Texas, but now its habitat has shrunk to just South Texas. It likes dense ground cover, but yet again, humans have removed most of the habitat it seeks. less 
Ocelot 
This endangered cat is about the size of a bobcat and is remarkable for its stunning markings. It used to roam a good bit of Texas, but now its habitat has shrunk to just South Texas. It likes dense Photo: Tanuki Photography, Texas Wildlife Image 6 of 14 
Louisiana black bear 
This subspecies of the American black bear used to roam East Texas and even as close to Houston as Washington County. Humans exterminated the last of the bears in Texas between 1900 and 1940. But because populations in other states are stable or increasing, sightings of bears, especially solitary males, in East Texas have been more numerous. Though the bears prize remoteness in their habitat, they may return to Texas. less

Humans exterminated the last of the bears in Texas between 1900 and Photo: AP/ Black Bear Conservation Committee Image 7 of 14 Whooping crane The only self-sustaining population of whooping cranes in the world winters at the Aransas National Wilidfe Refuge. The bird's numbers declined drastically as agriculture took over its summer home on the Great Plains. In Texas, it is highly vulnerable to oil spills. less Whooping crane The only self-sustaining population of whooping cranes in the world winters at the Aransas National Wilidfe Refuge. The bird's numbers declined drastically as agriculture took over its summer home ... more Photo: Kathy Adams Clark Image 8 of 14 Red-cockaded woodpecker This woodpecker is unusual in that it makes its homes in cavities in mature pine trees. Because such treeshave become more rare, so has the woodpecker. Its existing populations in Texas are, for the most part, in the national forests in the Piney Woods. less Red-cockaded woodpecker This woodpecker is unusual in that it makes its homes in cavities in mature pine trees. Because such treeshave become more rare, so has the woodpecker. Its existing populations in Texas ... more Photo: Michael Paulsen, Houston Chronicle Image 9 of 14 
Attwater's prairie chicken 
This bird holds the unwanted distinction of being one of the most endangered in the world. It lives only in coastal prairie. Over time it has lost 97 percent of its historic habitat due to human encroachment and urban sprawl. less
